children.title: CO2e Reduction potential, and Future (result after reduction)

children.text:
üí®
We're not in the business of reducing CO2 emission for your company. There are many wonderful experts and resources that can help with that.

We're here to point out that deleting the code that runs your low value features, can only have a positive impact on your emissions, while at the same time cutting the cost of operation.
It really is a win-win, even if the size of the environmental win is difficult to estimate.

However, we gave it a go anyway, and we think you can be emitting between

a month less, if you were to sunset your low value features.

We wrote a bit about what our thought process
Hi, we're Verdant - a product and growth consultancy with a focus on sustainable practices for SaaS products.

caption.text: Product and growth consulting with focus on sustainable practices for SaaS products.

children.text: We help SaaS products find a balance between thriving and reducing the negative impact on the environment.

Our goal is to help businesses operate with their core value proposition, helping them maximise the value capture from their target audience and reduce their cost and CO2 emissions by sunsetting unused features.
This tool is developed with assumptions and benchmarks, simply because it's extremely challenging to produce a tool that can do exact calculations, without having full access to your systems.
If you'd like us to create a version that is tailored for your business, we'd be happy to work on it with you.
Book us for a non-binding chat here:
If you're seeing this page from someone else's machine, scan the QR code for the link:

Understanding your core audience, they problems and how your product solves them is a competitive advantage that allows you to:

- Invest more in your value driving features
- Cut the cost of maintenance and computing
- Reduce CO2 emissions of your product
stage, can operate as successfully as today (and likely even more successfully), while:

You have nothing to loose and loads to gain by sunsetting them.

*This calculation is built on benchmarks and assumptions explained in the supporting tabs and it is only meant to showcase the principle benefits of focusing on your target audience. For specific calculations and recommendations on what features to sunset, contact Verdant:
% of your product's features are generating most of the value for your customers and your business.
But your teams are also spending time on about
% that don't have a positive impact on your bottom line.
Let's break this down. Each product has, in various degrees of distribution, these 4 groups of features:
- the reason why people buy those products, responsible for most of the product result.
- these are not your value drivers, but the product would be incomplete without them
Features that are missing their feature-market-fit
- for example, a vertical expansion that wasn't driven to a successful outcome, but due to a minor adoption, they were never removed
- series of POCs that were launched as prototypes, but never given the time needed to be improved or removed. No adoption, no usage, but every now and then they might cause something new to break
The distribution of the features will be different from one company to another, but most will fall into one of the categories, depending on the product maturity and company stage*
*This is a generalisation, the actual numbers will vary depending on a lot more factors, including how disciplined your teams are at removing low value code.
years old, a typical distribution of features based on their ability to drive value would look something like this:

children.title: Typical distribution of features based on their ability to drive value for a company like yours

children.text: In an attempt to explore if Pareto principle applies to digital products, in 2019, Pendo's research team analysed all software with installed Pendo tags, and found that features that usually drive highest enagement make for only 12% of the total features.

caption.text: Feature adoption, from Pendo's "The 2019 Feature Adoption Report"

children.text:
Using an aggregation of anonymised Pendo usage data over a three-month period, we determined that an average of 12% of features generate 80% of average daily usage volume. Meanwhile, 80% of features are rarely or never used. These percentages vary only slightly by size of company, making us confident that we can use them as a proxy for the broader software industry. The sample also included companies from numerous
verticals including banking/finance, HR technology, education, shipping and logistics, healthcare and e-commerce.
In our experience, we found that this number usually fits a large companies with mature products, and that depending on the age and the complexity of the product, the feature distribution would vary.
of their time on bug-fixing, maintenance and improvements to the existing features.
Despite of what most roadmaps communicate, we don't just constantly build new features. A good amount of time needs to be spent on maintenance, improvements and bug-fixing.  And that's okay.
The problem occurs when we don't stop and evaluate if everything we keep fixing and maintaining should remain in production.
% of their time is spent on features and systems that don't work for you.

Every company is different, every product setup is unique. There are a lot of parameters that would impact the computing cost you might have, from how the code is written, how diligently it's maintained, what regions you might be using, and if you even use AWS. We're not getting into all of that, it's not our expertise.
We are focusing on painting the picture of the cost reduction that is possible if your product stopped keeping those low value features alive.
As a quick reminder, we're talking about
Based on what you told us and how that relates to some other companies out there, we estimate you're spending about
on your AWS each month, or

These estimates are fairly accurate but subject to variations in actual AWS usage patterns and optimisations each company might employ. The multipliers can vary significantly depending on specific workloads, architecture, and operational efficiencies.
Supporting evidence and assumptions that went into this calculation
To paint this picture, we operated with following assumptions and benchmarks:
When it comes to the cloud providers, AWS has the majority of the market, with the share of about 50.1% (
Until we know better, we'll just assume you're using AWS, too.
#2 The more mature your product might be, the higher the cost
Typically lower AWS usage compared to a scaleup.Multiplier:
Larger companies with more resources, optimized spending, and more legacy systems.Multiplier:
(depending on the comparison with companies like Netflix)

Typically, products that are in their finding Product-Market-Fit stage (StartUp) tend to have a lower AWS usage per customer, fewer customers, and often taking advantage of free tiers and low-cost instances. This is a well-known growth lever for AWS, where they work on getting startups on board early, with the expectation that their cloud spending will increase as they scale‚Äã in the future (

Mature products, on the other side, tend to have a much higher AWS cost, usually due to their legacy systems, massive scale, higher utilisation of advanced AWS services like AI, big data, and container orchestration.
AI supporting functions but not the main driver.Multiplier:
Besides stage of growth, the age of the product (or age since the last full refactor or rewrite) will additionally impact the AWS cost.

Younger products are typically more optimised, with less unused or legacy code;  growing products begin to accumulate more legacy code and complexity; and once a product hits 10 years, it's considered mature with substantial legacy elements.
AI supporting functions but not the main driver.Multiplier:
#3 Your low value features use less power to run then your most used features
If we only focus on your feature distribution and which ones are most used, we can safely assume that they don't all utilise your AWS equally. More usage, higher utilisation.

Features or services that are "often used" are likely to account for a significant portion of AWS costs. This is because these features typically involve high-resource services like EC2 instances, databases (RDS), and extensive data transfer activities. According to AWS Cost and Usage Reports (CUR), these can represent 70-80% of the total AWS cost when utilized intensively ‚Äã(

Features that are "sometimes used" contribute less to overall costs, often because they may not involve sustained high-resource usage or because they benefit from cost-optimization measures like reserved instances or spot pricing. These typically account for 10-20% of total costs ‚Äã(

"Rarely used" features, though consuming resources, do so inefficiently, contributing around 5-10% of the cost. Features that are "never used" should ideally not incur any cost, but in practice, they might still consume minimal resources due to residual configurations or maintenance needs, contributing approximately 1-2% to the total cost ‚Äã(
So while your low value features comparably incur lower cost than the more used ones, we still ask:
each month on something that doesn't do anything for you?
#4 Your target audience type will have a major impact on your cost

environments often experience significant fluctuations in traffic due to events, promotions, and seasonal changes, which demand highly elastic and responsive cloud services.  AWS costs are higher here because of the need for services that can scale rapidly and handle large volumes of user interactions simultaneously‚Äã (
companies often deploy extensive customer engagement tools such as chatbots, recommendation engines, and personalised marketing, all of which are resource-intensive and drive up cloud costs (
The need for continuous availability and responsiveness in these systems for B2C-focused businesses have a tendency to incur a higher cost on the cloud computing services.
workloads are typically more stable, with less dramatic traffic spikes, allowing for more predictable and potentially lower AWS costs due to fewer requirements for auto-scaling and burst capacity‚Äã(

companies may focus more on reliability and specific service levels for fewer, high-value clients, potentially lowering the overall need for elastic resources but increasing the cost of individual transactions due to the complexity of the services offered‚Äã(
Lower AWS usage per customer, more predictable workload.Multiplier:
#5 Offering Storage as a Service inflates the cost

For companies where storage is a key part of their service, storage-related costs are a critical factor in the overall AWS cost structure. The type of storage, frequency of data access, data transfer volumes, and long-term storage strategies all play significant roles in determining the total cost. Proper storage management and cost optimization strategies are essential to keep AWS expenses under control.

The inclusion of storage in your AWS architecture can significantly increase costs, particularly when data is stored long-term and never deleted. Short-term storage adds a moderate increase, while long-term storage, especially as data accumulates, can result in substantial cost increases.
We're not going to get this part right.
There are so many issues with this calculation
We're not experts in CO2e calculations
We're using our estimation of your monthly AWS cost as the base for estimating CO2e.
The benchmarks are not publicly available, and even for those that disclose the Co2e data, the suspicion is that the actual numbers are almost double of the reported ones (
Attribution is a b***, and we could easily lose ourselves trying to map everything correctly
A lot can go wrong in this calculation, and even the margin of error is not that clear.

But here's something we're certain of: 

Deleting the code that runs your low value features, deleting the data that doesn't get accessed - it can only have a positive impact on your emissions, while at the same time cutting the cost of operation. 

It really is a win-win, even if the size of the environmental win is difficult to estimate.
But let's give the estimate a try, regardless‚Ä¶

Here's what we did: in order to calculate the CO2 emissions from cloud computing services, we estimated the energy consumption and then converted that into carbon emissions using regional and AWS-specific emission factors.
We also incorporated the factors like the fact that your product is in the
stage, that between business and consumers, your target audience is
, that you'd describe your level of utilisation of AI as

If you're using AWS, then use their Customer Carbon Footprint Tool and calculate your Scope 1 and 2 emissions. The tool is described in more detail in this blog:
